channel.title: INfinance
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from INfinance, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: UnitedHealthcare exec’s murder exposes a deeper problem no one wants to face
item.description: Why is health insurance in the hands of private, profit-seeking, profit-maximizing organizations in the first place?

item.title: His Will Was a Selfie Video, but Courts Ruled It Didn't Count
item.description: Why the written word is still the final word in estate planning.

item.title: The WSJ Dollar Index Rises 0.1% to 101.21
item.description: The WSJ Dollar Index was up 0.1% to 101.21 — higher for six consecutive trading days.

item.title: Tinder's Tough Love Should Ultimately Serve Match Well
item.description: Growth expected to get worse before an overhaul takes hold, but low valuation keeps expectations in check.

item.title: Trump says he’ll ‘make housing affordable again.’ Here’s how to ease the crisis.
item.description: America needs more new homes — and more renovated homes. House ‘flippers’ are key.

item.title: The S&P 500 at 4,800? That’s what some Wall Street experts predicted — for 2024.
item.description: Your best stock-market advice for 2025? Pay no attention to stock-market predictions, which are frequently — and comically — wrong.

item.title: A retirement expert’s best advice? Don’t retire.
item.description: Economist Alicia Munnell spoke to MarketWatch about the retirement “crisis” and her biggest financial regrets.

item.title: Why the case against a Roth conversion gets stronger if Trump’s tax cuts continue
item.description: Break-even point for a Roth conversion is long —and extending the 2017 tax cuts could make it longer.

item.title: Dow Industrials Fall Slightly; Treasury Yields Rise on Inflation Concerns
item.description: U.S. stocks bounced between gains and losses before ending mixed as concerns about softer spending by lower-income customers dragged down consumer-goo...

item.title: The Drugs Young Bankers Use to Get Through the Day---and Night
item.description: Many on Wall Street see Adderall and Vyvanse as tools to plow through long hours of tedious work amid high-pressure competition.
